qas.question: Which bishop didn't realize the satirical nature of Burke's book?
Which lord didn't realize the satirical nature of Burke's book?
When was the 2nd edition of Burke's book published?
Where did Burke make it clear that his book was a satire?

answers.text: in the preface to the second edition

qas.question: What did Lord Chesterfield believe Bolingbroke's arguments could also apply to?
What did critics particularly protest of Burke's work?
What did Burke note in the preface of the first edition of the book?
Which bishop wrote the preface for Burke's book?

context: Burke claimed that Bolingbroke's arguments against <b4_0>revealed religion<b4_0/> could apply to <b5_0>all social and civil institutions<b5_0/> as well. <a1_0>Lord Chesterfield<a1_0/> and <a0_0>Bishop <b8_0>Warburton<b8_0/><a0_0/> (and others) initially thought that the work was genuinely by Bolingbroke rather than a satire. All the reviews of the work were positive, with critics especially appreciative of <b6_0>Burke's quality of writing<b6_0/>. Some reviewers failed to notice the ironic nature of the book, which led to Burke stating <a3_0>in the preface to the second edition<a3_0/> (<a2_0>1757<a2_0/>) <b7_0>that it was a satire<b7_0/>.
